text.__SUMMARY__: Tropidophis feicki, also known as the broad-banded dwarf boa or Feick's dwarf boa, is a species of snake in the family Tropidophiidae. The species is endemic to Cuba.
text.Etymology: The specific name, feicki, is in honor of American biologist John R. Feick.
text.Description: Tropidophis feicki males can grow to 41 cm (16 in) snout-vent length (SVL), and females to 45 cm (18 in). There are 217–235 ventral scales and 34–41 subcaudal scales. The dorsal ground color is grey or pink. There is a saddle pattern dorsally, but no ventral pattern.
text.Geographic range: T. feicki is found in western Cuba, from Pedrera de Mendoza and Guane, Pinar del Río Province, east to Pan de Matanzas, Matanzas Province.
text.Habitat: The preferred habitat of T. feicki is upland caves, cliffs, and talus deposits.
text.Further reading: Schwartz A (1957). "A New Species of Boa (Genus Tropidophis) from Western Cuba". American Museum Novitates (1839): 1-8. (Tropidophis feicki, new species).
